content.text: So far, our predicates have taken one argument: 'Runs(x)', 'Happy(alice)'. But many statements involve **relations** between two or more things: 'Alice loves Bob', 'Paris is between London and Berlin', '3 is less than 5'.

content.definition: A predicate that takes two or more arguments. A binary relation takes 2 arguments, a ternary relation takes 3, and so on.

content.title: Common Relations
premises: Between(paris, london, berlin) — Paris is between London and Berlin
Gave(alice, book, bob) — Alice gave a book to Bob
content.note: The order of arguments matters! Loves(alice, bob) and Loves(bob, alice) are different claims.

content.definition: A special relation that holds when two terms refer to the same thing. Written as a = b or =(a,b).

content.text: With relations and quantifiers together, we can express complex statements: 'Everyone loves someone' becomes ∀x∃y(Loves(x,y)), and 'Someone is loved by everyone' becomes ∃y∀x(Loves(x,y)).

content.question: How would you translate 'John is taller than Mary'?
content.explanation: 'Taller than' is a binary relation between two people. TallerThan(john, mary) captures 'John is taller than Mary' with John as the first argument.
